ARABIC: تَجْرِى بِأَعْيُنِنَا جَزَآءً لِّمَن كَانَ كُفِرَ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: which ran before Our eyes - a reward for him who had been rejected.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: Which sailed right under Our eyes: A recompense for him who had been denied.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: which sailed on under Our supervision: a reward for him who had been shown ingratitude.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: which floated on the water before Our very eyes. The flood was a recompense for the deeds of the disbelievers.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: Sailing in front of Our sight; as a reward for the sake of one who was rejected.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Floating under Our Eyes, a reward for him who had been rejected!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: Sailing, before Our eyes, a reward for him who was denied.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: running before Our eyes-a recompense for him denied.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: That ran (upon the waters) in Our sight, as a reward for him who was rejected.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: floated on under Our eyes: a vindication of him who had been rejected.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: Moving forward under Our eyes: a requital for him who had been rejected.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: which sailed [over the flood waters] in Our sight, as a retribution for him who was met with disbelief.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: She floats under our eyes (and care): a recompense to one who had been rejected (with scorn)!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Floating under Our Eyes, a reward for him who had been rejected!
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: that ran on under Our Eyes, a recompense for him because he had been disbelieved.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: Sailing before Our eyes; a reward for him who was rejected.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: Sailing under Our observation as reward for he who had been denied.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [54:14] sailing before Our eyes, that is, in Our sights, in other words, [it was being] protected, as retaliation (jazā’an is in the accusative because of the implied verbal clause, that is to say, ‘they were drowned by way of revenge’) for [the sake of] him who was rejected, namely, Noah, peace be upon him (a variant reading [for passive kufira] has kafara, ‘him who disbelieved’, in other words, they were drowned as a punishment for them).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (That ran (upon the waters) in Our sight) under Our protection, (as a reward for him who was rejected) He says: this is as a reward for the folk of Noah as a result of their disbelief.
